image.altText: Grove bus stop 2025-02-25 11:02:00

props.synopsis: Locals warn they've seen "many near misses" between schoolkids and cars at a notorious bus stop along Tasmania's Huon Highway that was the site of an accident this week.

title.children: 'It's ridiculous': Boy hospitalised after incident at bus stop known for 'near misses'

image.altText: A close-up of a woman wearing a t-shirt, wrapping her arms around her pregnant belly

props.synopsis: Federal government funding will allow Hobart's maternity services to expand at both Calvary and the Royal Hobart hospitals.

title.children: Maternity services to expand in Hobart following private service closure

image.altText: Map of Robbins Island with dots for wind farms and orange-bellied parrots.

props.synopsis: A critically endangered species of parrot migrates through the Tasmanian site where a wind farm is planned with data proving it, a bird expert says — contradicting previous claims made by the company. That should be enough to stop the proposal, the ecologist says.

title.children: 'Clear' evidence critically endangered birds use site of proposed wind farm, expert says

image.altText: An unidentified doctor holds a pile of red, yellow and white complementary medicine pills in their outstretched hands.

props.synopsis: Almost 10 years after being directed to regulate unregistered health practitioners to better protect the public, some parts of Australia still haven't got around to it.

title.children: Calls for greater regulation as people running 'wellness centres out of their living room'

image.altText: A navy ship in the ocean.

props.synopsis: Defence officials believe a Chinese nuclear-powered submarine accompanied the flotilla during its deployment off Australia's coast, which involved controversial live-fire exercises in the Tasman Sea.

title.children: Submarine suspected to be with Chinese warship 300km from Hobart

image.altText: Concept art showing interior of sports stadium with cricket match underway.

props.synopsis: If it wasn't already official, it is now: The proposed Hobart stadium is massively on the nose among many Tasmanians, especially in the Liberal stronghold of the north-west.

title.children: Poll reveals support levels for proposed Hobart stadium across Tasmania

image.altText: A stand of thousands of trees still green with bushfire burnt up to the edge.

props.synopsis: When fire maps showed a bushfire in Tasmania's west burning within metres of a high-conservation-value stand of ancient trees, there were fears for the worst.

title.children: Aerials reveal how close we came to losing 3,000-year-old Huon pine

image.altText: an asian woman applying liner to her eyebrows

props.synopsis: On the surface, these 40-minute-long ads on Facebook and Instagram appear to be make-up tutorials. An ABC NEWS Verify investigation has uncovered how a dubious online store is using them to hawk erectile dysfunction supplements.

title.children: These Facebook ads promise to 'unlock your confidence'. It's porn in disguise

props.synopsis: Greens senator Sarah Hanson-Young has called for the board and chief executive of Creative Australia to be sacked after it chose to withdraw the contract of a Lebanese-Australian artist to represent Australia in Venice.

title.children: Greens call for Creative Australia board to go amid Venice Biennale controversy — as it happened

image.altText: A woman kisses a baby.

props.synopsis: There are growing calls for an independent inquiry into a series of deaths and medical traumas at Latrobe Regional Hospital.

title.children: More families speak out as pressure builds to review avoidable child deaths in hospital

image.altText: Trump signs executive orders from the Oval Office

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers meets with his American counterpart in a bid to spare Australia from hefty tariffs on steel and aluminium. It come as Donald Trump flags possible tariffs on copper imports.

title.children: Trump flags copper tariffs as Chalmers takes exemption case to DC

image.altText: A man watches the information screens at the ASX

props.synopsis: Australian shares fall, with results from Woolworths, WiseTech, Lynas and Flight Centre. US President Donald Trump has ordered an investigation into a new tariff on copper imports.

title.children: ASX falls as Woolworths, WiseTech, Flight Centre, Lynas report

image.altText: A man out of focus stands at a street intersection in a rural town where the road is covered in brown water.

props.synopsis: The peak body for insurers wants the next federal government to stump up $30 billion to protect homes against an onslaught of climate-fuelled flooding predicted to batter Australian communities in the coming decades.

title.children: Insurance industry pitches plan to help households drowning in costs

image.altText: A navy ship in the ocean.

props.synopsis: Defence officials believe a Chinese nuclear-powered submarine accompanied the flotilla during its deployment off Australia's coast, which involved controversial live-fire exercises in the Tasman Sea.

title.children: Intelligence chief says Chinese warship deployment designed to be 'provocative'

image.altText: A student walks toward the quadrangle at the University of Sydney.

props.synopsis: Australia's 39 universities have endorsed a new definition of antisemitism that will be enforced on campus after coming under pressure from a senate inquiry following rancorous protests regarding the Gaza war.

title.children: New definition of antisemitism endorsed by 39 universities

image.altText: A boy with brown hair sits on his mum's lap, touches her faces and smiles into her eyes with greenery behind them.

props.synopsis: Australians with intellectual disability continue to experience unconscious bias in the medical system and poor health outcomes. Advocates are demanding change.

title.children: The Australians with health outcomes 'like third world countries'

image.altText: A smiling woman with tattoos on her arm wearing glasses sitting in a black wheelchair

props.synopsis: Belle Owen was excited to buy her first home, but it was not exactly perfect – a year in, it still is not fully accessible. There are hopes recent changes to the National Construction Code will improve housing options, but some advocates say it does not go far enough.

title.children: Inaccessible housing means people are 'crawling' to get to their own bathrooms

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: crashing waves with grey storm clouds overhead

props.synopsis: There is a high probability Cyclone Alfred, currently around 1,000 kilometres offshore, will cross one of the most highly populated stretches of the Australian coast next week.

title.children: New weather modelling predicts Cyclone Alfred's imminent arrival

image.altText: Yoon Suk Yeol on a television screen

props.synopsis: Mr Yoon has denied any wrongdoing and blamed the main liberal opposition Democratic Party, which obstructed his agenda, impeached senior officials and slashed key parts of the government’s budget bill.

title.children: South Korea's Yoon Suk Yeol defends his martial law decree as impeachment trial nears end

image.altText: Go-Jo, with black hair and short moustache, posing in a multi-coloured singlet.

props.synopsis: Sydney-based Marty Zambotto, who first went viral for his music in 2023, will be the 10th act to represent Australia when Eurovision begins in Switzerland later this year.

title.children: Viral pop sensation Go-Jo to represent Australia at Eurovision 2025

image.altText: A large wind turbine blade across a suburban street.

props.synopsis: The 70-metre-long blade was being trucked through Ararat in Victoria when it became apparent that it would be impossible to get it around a corner or for the vehicle to turn back.

title.children: Council demands compensation after wind turbine blade debacle

image.altText: Picture of Australian one dollar coins stacked on top of note currency

props.synopsis: Increasing amounts of investment dollars are moving into the private realm and the number of companies on stock exchanges is declining, catching the attention of ASIC.

title.children: Why the shift towards private investment has our regulators worried

image.altText: A boat with two men, one white, one Indigenous holding a turtle at the edge of the boat ready for release. Water in foreground

props.synopsis: Protection of Australia's oceans is shaping up to be a federal election issue for coastal communities as rangers and researchers work to battle illegal fishing, pollution and climate change.

title.children: Federal parties vie over ocean protection ahead of election

image.altText: A close up shot of Keir Starmer in a room.

props.synopsis: British Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer says the spending boost, worth $26 billion, was designed to counter Russian aggression, amid uncertainty in Europe about the US' commitment to their defence.

title.children: UK to boost defence spending to Cold War levels by cutting aid budget

image.altText: Two women sit on a rock wall with a man in front of a beach cabin.

props.synopsis: Australia’s beach shacks are an architectural quirk of history. But as they slowly disappear from our coastlines, ‘shackies’ and historians argue we should be paying more attention to the hidden history of these emblems of summer.

title.children: Inside the humble beach shack, a reminder of endless Australian summers

image.altText: Alex de Minaur holds up his hand

props.synopsis: Marin Cilic spoils the prospect of an all-Aussie showdown in Dubai by beating Alex de Minaur, but Chris O'Connell joins Alexei Popyrin in the last 16.

title.children: Shock de Minaur defeat ruins hopes of all-Aussie showdown in Dubai

image.altText: Jim Chalmers holds his arms out while speaking at a press conference at parliament house

props.synopsis: The Treasury costings were at the centre of a political storm, with Angus Taylor suggesting the public service was used inappropriately.

title.children: Chalmers cherry-picked Treasury's costing of Coalition lunch policy

image.altText: A man in an airport's Qantas lounge, a glass of wine is resting on a nearby table.

props.synopsis: Queensland Opposition Leader Steven Miles has complained to Qantas after photos were taken of him and shared in parliament.

title.children: Steven Miles complains to Qantas about 'on the red wine' lounge photo

image.altText: Photo of Cairns police watch house entrance including signs on door saying 'No Smoking'

props.synopsis: Queensland's police commissioner has promised to investigate allegations a 12-year-old disabled boy was coerced into drinking toilet water at a watch house.

title.children: Queensland police to 'fully' investigate watch house allegations

image.altText: Surinder Kumar crouches as he poses with a group of male migrants gathered near a gold coach.

props.synopsis: A perilous journey across continents, jungles and mountains does not always end in the American dream, but some Indian migrants are selling land and risking everything for a chance at life in the US.

title.children: Smuggled, shackled, sent back — Indians risk it all for American dream

image.altText: Three air conditioners on an orange wall.

props.synopsis: Queensland’s power companies can force thousands of air conditioners in homes into low-power mode on the hottest days of the year. Experts say systems like this need to be part of the energy solution.

title.children: Giving up control of your air conditioner may reduce blackouts: experts

image.altText: Woman pray shoulder to shoulder in a mosque

props.synopsis: The Islamic holy month is always held on the ninth month of the Islamic Lunar calendar.

title.children: When is Ramadan 2025 and how is it celebrated?

image.altText: Pines in front of old building

props.synopsis: Trees that have become icons of Australian beachfronts are facing threats from humans and dry weather, a university researcher says.

title.children: Decline of iconic tree may be fuelled by climate change and poisonings

image.altText: A man with very short dark hair in a white button up shirt sits n a flooded balcony looks serious.

props.synopsis: Thomas Ockenfels bought his Canberra apartment more than two years ago, and then realised water was prone to seeping into his bedroom when it rained. His attempts to get his strata company to address the issue have cast light on a growing issue.

title.children: Though rain leaks into his unit, Thomas says his strata doesn't help
